Character actors Ben Foster, Alan Tudyk, and legendary Peter Fonda perfectly fill their supporting roles. But the whole affair has a been there-done that feel to it. It's a derivative western, with wagon chases, horse chases, gun battles, and an epic shoot-out set piece at the train station where that train is coming at 3:10. All well-done, if flashy and unoriginal. Crowe's character seems too carefully crafted--he draws, he's literate-minded, and shows flashes of a caring heart. Crowe can pull it off smoothly, being cold-blooded when called upon and philosophical when needed. But it robs his arc of impact, and ends up being glib and unsatisfying. As modern westerns go, 'No Country for Old Men' and 'The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada' still hold the crown as classics. This one, for all its fine acting and thrilling action beats, can't match the frontier sweep and deep, psychological morality that IS the western

3:10 to Yuma exhilarates the viewer with a gripping and thoroughly original story that always leaves one enticingly uncertain about the next turn of events. This is a laudable quality for a genre generally characterized by stereotypes and cliches. Of particular interest is the unique dynamic which permeates the relationship between protagonist Dan Evans and the outlaw Ben Wade, enabling the film to consistently impress the viewer with its willingness to permit its characters the gift of true depth and complexity. There are no simple archetypes here; as a result, we grow to care about the outcomes of the film's central conflicts on a more deeply human level. Among the one or two developments which stretch the viewer's credulity, I must include the Fonda character's unlikely ability to stoically recuperate from a shot in the gut at near point-blank range, essentially shrugging the injury off following an improbably laid back experience of 19th century bullet-removal surgery. Petty qualms aside, 3:10 to Yuma presents the Western in a refreshingly unique light, achieving a level of depth uncharacteristic of the simple morality tales which the genre typically embodies.

The good father wants to be respected and admired by his family, regarded as a model of integrity and competence by his children, and seen as a devoted provider by his partner. But what if his body is damaged by war, his property threatened by corrupt men, and his means of providing has strict limits? Then that wish strays further from his grasp. It would take a unique opportunity to turn things around, to allow him to become the leader he yearns to be.
     Christian Bale as Dan Evans is a marvel of restraint in his portrayal of a decent, but frustrated rancher, trying to keep his property from being taken by the railroad company. In this post-civil war era western, Evans gets his chance to reverse his fortune by escorting a dangerous, captured outlaw, Ben Wade (Cameron Crowe) on the 3:10 train to Yuma to stand trial. His reward money for this feat would be enough to clear him of all debts and, more importantly, allow him to reclaim his spot as the respected head of his family instead of being seen as a lame war veteran, lacking the means to stake his claim to his homestead. 
     I'm not especially drawn to the western genre, but this modern remake by James Mangold is thoroughly entertaining as it balances well-paced plotting, intriguing characterization, and fantastic acting by the two leads. I've never enjoyed Crowe more in a role than this one. He is perfect as the charismatic criminal, drawing out equal parts admiration and disgust from those around him, including Evans' oldest son who, on the threshold of manhood, seeks to succeed where his father has failed and wonders whether Wade may have more valuable life lessons than his own dad. Wade unapologetically follows his own bliss, whether that means deep diving into literature and the bible, or remorselessly snuffing out lives to gain advantage for himself. 
     Once the pistols are holstered and the story concludes, the one thing that lingers is the relationship between the two leads. There is grudging admiration by each for the other's talents. While Crowe's character seduces with his plainspoken views about whether a person deserves respect or deserves to die, there is also a part of him that longs to be the stalwart, committed and disciplined man represented by Evans (Bale). This is a perfectly realized film, that fires on all cylinders: story, action, conflict, theme, acting, and cinematic splendour. Whether you love the western genre or not, this is an absorbing morality tale, cloaked in tense action sequences and top notch acting. I rate it required viewing!

Russell Crowe as Ben Wade: complex, brilliant, courageous and absolutely uncompromising in his own inner compass. He cuts through all the pretenses of those around him since he was not blind to his own, or better said, he did NOT allow himself to have any for himself. In his ever encounter, from the bar maid to Will Evans (Dan Evan's son), his incisive and laser awareness of their psychology gives the viewer a hint at the depth of the hidden sensitivity and intelligence of his character. Perhaps the most admirable quality about Ben Wade is his no B.S. authenticity to himself and then to others. He makes no excuses for his way of being and is fully aware of the entirety of how he fits with broad picture of society. Becaue of this, he has no need to make embelishments for who and what he is and neither does he have false humility. He is an outlaw and lives it fully and with no compromise or excuses. 
I find this aspect of Ben Wade as quite refreshing when seen in the context of the average man who is beset with endless guilt and self-doubt in EVERYTHING they do. Ben Wade is like the vulture or the ants in the forest floor. He knows his role in the great circle of life and fulfills it with no fuss or muss. 
The movie is actually a bromance between Ben Wade and Dan Evans. Their encounter with each other brings out the deepest, perhaps tenderest, aspect of themselves which heretofore had been dormant. The many scenes of their short conversations with each other are filled with nuances of the trust/intimacy they began to experience in each other's company. It is safe to say, specially with the way the movie ended, there has not been anyone in each of their lives with whom they had been willing to expose so much of themselves to the other. It may very well be how it is when we know death is just around the corner -- it heightens every experience and encounter.

James Mangold's Western crime drama 3:10 to Yuma (2007) is a blistering race to a train station to bring a criminal to jail. It pits a desperate farmer against a clever gang leader and his insanely devoted thugs.

Mangold's direction has never looked better or felt so grounded. Mangold updated the Western genre with a quicker pace and tense scenes in order to keep the audience engaged. 3:10 to Yuma is as entertaining as Westerns get.

Christian Bale is so relatable and sympathetic as the lead Dan Evans. Russell Crowe is a charming villain and terrifying killer as Ben Wade. Ben Foster is a scene stealing killer without a conscious as Charlie Prince. These 3 leads complete 3:10 to Yuma powerhouse cast of actors in their prime all commanding each scene with their notable presence.

Logan Lerman is really good as the belligerent teenager William Evans and gets some interesting moments. Peter Fonda is a tough Pinkerton Byron McElroy with an axe to grind. Dallas Roberts is perfect as the cowardly Grayson Butterfield.

The shootouts and violent and thrilling that keep you glued to the screen. But, the best scenes are Bale and Crowe exchanging insults, comebacks, and pasts with their respective ethos in life on full display. It's like they develop a respect for each other on screen before our eyes. 3:10 to Yuma delivers one of cinema's most ponderous friendships with its blistering finale. The last conversation between Bale and Crowe while they hide out in the station is fascinating and moving. Their acting prowess coupled with Macro Beltrami's touching and enchanting Western score culminate in cinematic euphoria. Bale and Crowe give nuanced performances, while they tear up the screen with a slash of bullets.

Lastly, I really liked Gretchen Mol as Alice Evans. Her scenes opposite Bale draw out the best and most sincere lines from Bale. When he admits he is embarrassed at how everyone looks down on him to her, I was just silenced by his aura. Mol plays the uncertain and worried wife with a stern realism and a quiet grace.

The style of 3:10 to Yuma is amazing, and I’m starting to think I need to catch up on more of James Mangold’s filmography. He knows how to capture stunning visuals and thrilling action. I was riveted by most of this movie simply because he utilized all the tools in his arsenal to keep the intensity cranked up. One of the most vital aspects of this story is that there is always a sense of impending doom because the odds are stacked against our heroes. That’s how it felt throughout the film, and even the calmer moments were presented in a way that allowed us to sense the possible danger. I liked the characters in the film as well, because even though they were filling traditional roles they all had nuance to make them more complex than the stereotypes we’d typically see in a Western. Unfortunately, there are two big problems with 3:10 to Yuma that kept me from loving it, despite all the amazing elements that went into the film. The first issue is related to the plot. I have always struggled with films that start to feel pointlessly repetitive. It’s tedious to watch when the characters keep making the same stupid choices and seeing the same consequences played out in a slightly different fashion each time. The number of times that Ben Wade is left without a gun pointed at him so that he can attack one of his captors or escape them is ludicrous. At a certain point I was yelling at the screen trying to figure out how they could let it happen again. It was like an endless cycle of ineptitude, and the fact that it kept repeating got boring at a certain point. There’s one other thing that just doesn’t work in 3:10 to Yuma, and this is something I’ve been proclaiming for years...Russell Crowe cannot act. His role in this film requires a lot of subtlety because he is a complex character who puts on a rough exterior while having more complicated thoughts inside. A strong actor would be able to pull this off so that we’d see the inner conflict in his performance. But with Crowe we have a guy who appears to act erratically because we have no sense that he’s making choices based on anything he’s feeling (he appears to feel nothing.) It’s a shame because the rest of the cast is crushing it, and the story has potential for brilliance, but there are a few choices that hold it back from achieving greatness.

3:10 to Yuma isn't perfect, but in a world where the western is all but dead, it's pretty enjoyable. Perhaps the most refreshing thing about the movie is its focus on characters over action scenes. There's plenty of the latter of course, especially in the third act, but it's primarily a character driven story revolving around troubled rancher Dan Evans and fierce outlaw Ben Wade. The relationship is really fascinating, but takes a hit during an abrupt change of character in the third act that is completely unnecessary. It's not enough to truly ruin the film, but it definitely makes an impression.

Evans and Wade are played by Christian Bale and Russell Crowe, respectively, and they're expectedly great coming from such talent: in particular, their banter back and forth really drives the film. Logan Lerman does solid work in a supporting role, and Ben Foster nearly steals the show with a delightfully crazy performance. Director James Mangold really seems to understand the western, as he nails the atmosphere in this one. The sets and costumes fit, and Marco Beltrami's score is subdued yet stunning.

With a few touch ups in the final act and maybe some reworked pacing, 3:10 to Yuma might be a superb western, but as it stands, it's not a bad time. At the very least, it's one of the few remakes that isn't completely horrible, which is always admirable.

The film looks great, has some thrilling action, has a great cast, and has some enjoyable characters.
The story is as follows.  You have a man named Dan Evans (Christian Bale) who is heavy in debt and has to leave his farm with his family if he doesn't pay them off.  Meanwhile you have a desperado named Ben Wade (Russell Crowe) and his men who rob a stage coach owned by McElroy (Peter Fonda) and nearly kill him.  Wade is arrested but they need to get him on the train to Yuma.  However, his men are still on the loose including his most loyal follower, Prince (Ben Foster), and will try to stop them.  The sheriff of the town, the doctor, Evans, McElroy, and even Evan's son, William (Logan Lerman), ban together to take Wade to justice while fending off his gang and other threats they encounter along the way.
As I said the film looks good and has some enjoyable action, but what stole the film was the cast and characters.  Russell Crowe and Christian Bale were excellent in the film and they played off each other great. 3:10 to Yuma - 3:10 to Horse Shit
(Be Advised - Spoilers)

On Monday, midday, I thought I'd treat myself to what in my family was termed a "funkie." That would be the movie you'd turn on on weekend afternoons, in the midst of the heat, that would usually be a gun opera or involve oversized lizards.

So my choice what a neuvo Western called "3:10 to Yuma," starring Russel Crowe and Christian Bale as the antagonist and protagonist, the charming sociopath and the frumpy one and one-half legged ex-Massachusetts militia man turned Arizona cow farmer. And then there's Ben Foster, the young actor who keeps getting case as quasi-psychotic weirdos or psychopaths, a la the boyfriend in Six Feet Under, or the creepy criminal in Bruce Willis' hostage movie, who burns himself to death at the denouement. And some miscellaneous bad guys, my favorite of which being the silent sharpshooter Mexican.

The thing I really didn't like about the film was not the improbabilities--why was the stage coach robbery so badly planned. I mean, they're running behind a coach loaded up with a backward-facing Gatling gun. Well, and for that matter, why doesn't that early machine gun hit more of them? It isn't that Ben Wade (Crowe) stays inexplicably in town after "taking" the comely frontier town bar wench (could they really have been that attractive and worked in a bar for long). It was the faux psychology. The last time I'd seen such a psychologically shallow film parading itself as something deep was Clint Eastwood's "The Unforgiven." That one won some award. Apparently there's a prize for most self-deluded.

I mean, how hard is it to make a Western? The template is already there, either in Eastwood's early films of the great operas of Sergio Leonne ("Once Upon a Time in the West" is about as good as it gets). You take archetypally exaggerated characters, pit them against each other in archetypally charged situations, and bring them to an archetypally loaded climax and conclusion. You don't need to fuss around with real motivation, with complexity of psychology and relationship. Unless you do, and then you have GOT to get it right.

If you're going to tell a story of human psyches, for God's sake, know what you're talking about. Don't get your information from other shallow movies that are pretending to be deep. Or maybe being as deep as they can, because they've never looked inside for their source material.

3:10 to Yuma was, I guess, as story of fathers and sons and redemption. In Wilberian terms, it's the story of the "red," self centered, ego-centric level of development maturing into an "blue," family/village-centric level of development, the story of the transition from the social form of the strong man to that of the strong law. Ok, fair enough. Deadwood, David Milch and HBO's fantastic ballad of civilization, did it for three years. It's a great subject, rich and deep.

Except for in this film. Just as in "The Unforgiven," human motivation is presented with the form of depth--yes, fathers and sons have complex relationships, and sons have to choose their idealized figures and then come to grips with their real world men; darkness must be struggled with and brought to the light, socially, interpersonally, and intrapsychically--but it doesn't actually have the substance. It's like someone quoting Shakespeare, and at first it seems they are taking those pieces that are meaningful, yet pretty soon you realize they are spouting those parts that they believe are deep, because of what they've heard or read. But not what they have felt.

That's this film: callow, un-heart felt, bleak in its confused morality, shallow in its understanding of human nature and minds. Blah.

3:10 to Yuma tells the story of a rancher who is about to lose his farm, so he agrees to escort an infamous outlaw to the next town so he can put him on the 3:10 train to Yuma prison.  However, the journey proves to have many surprises and requires more tough decisions than he ever suspected.  Neither of these characters are flat. The word remake differ in tone depending on the genre of films. In horror it's very common to expect nothing that'll match the original with the remake failing to understand what worked and what didn't the first time around. In the action genre it's obligatory that the remake will either be a rehashed, worse than the original, and at times overshadow a good film due to its poor reputation. For Western the word remake is a more positive phrase as "The Magnificent Seven" and "True Grit" match their original counterpart. The difference with "3:10 To Yuma" being it's one of the rare occasion where many believe the remake surpasses the original.

3:10 To Yuma is about a small-time rancher agreeing to escort a captured outlaw who's awaiting a train to go to court in Yuma. Driven by it characters rather than a conventional goal. The plot is traditionally simple and with modern complexity presented in the characters. It two central characters analyze not only each other, but the depiction of the old west. Both the lawmen and outlaws take liberty in action to get what their job done. Dealing with the ideas of honor, respect, pride, and the ultimate question what is good and what is bad or what is right and what is wrong. It doesn't pick a side rather it more explores the depth of morality. Portrayal of the old West remains realistic until the final act becoming over the top for an appropriate reason. While it is established (or predicted by the viewers) that nothing would be gained if the destination was met for either central characters it doesn't take away anything from the character's arc. 

Unfortunately despite having compelling villain he is sadly a plot device. Not bad in a traditional sense he serves nothing, but in the way he can't suffer negative consequences while being held captive. Upon killing one of his captors he must remained unharmded because the plot needs him in good condition for the climax. Our heroes morality is tackled when debating to kill the criminal on the spot; however, the heroes make several bad decisions during their journey you know they won't turn against the law. You'll never feel the lawmen will become an outlaw nor the fear for a second care for the outlaw life in risk given how well he's treated by his lawmen. The ending can garner mixed results. It's an ending that is wholly satisfying and nonsensical. Closing the film two central character arc in manner that makes a reflection on one man life as lie and one man life as the truth. Nonsensical thinking upon it as nothing was accomplished by our central character and that each seal their fate knowing the outcome of their action. As a character study it succeeds in area you wouldn't expect it too, but the narrative never makes it come full circle.

Christian Bale plays his role quiet low key, controlled, and generates considerable sympathy for him. Russell Crowe is equally match Bale as a clever and ruthless leader of his gang of robbers, but his very subtle take that his character is getting tired of his life, and his gradual bonding to Bale worth watching. Ben Foster portrays a borderline psychotic in a manner that also avoids stereotyping in good performance. These actors are supported by good supporting actors by Peter Fonda, Alan Tudyk, Dallas Roberts, and Logan Lerman. In fact it is the character interplay is the driving heart of the film, and keeps you transfixed throughout. This interplay is brilliantly facilitated by writer-director Mangold, who sets it in a spectacular environment and embellishes the story well-handled complexities.

3:10 To Yuma is an intelligent character studied even if the story it tells is not on the level of wit as the characters we analyze. It's a Western that is founded by its actor interplay and character interactions under James Mangold direction that give it great success. No matter if you're a die hard Western fan or not one in favor of the genre "3:10 To Yuma" contains strong characters and equally powerful cast that complements an intelligent look at the old west.

3:10 to Yuma, a remake of the movie made 50 years earlier, is a classic Western in every sense, and I mean that in the best and worst way. Christian Bale plays a man who joins a posse to take Russell Crowe's character, Ben Wade, an infamous outlaw, to a train set to depart at 3:10 to Yuma in a town 3 days away. The story is not highly developed, but Westerns have never relied on complex stories, rather straightforward ones that are done well, and this fits that bill quite well. Christian Bale does an okay job, but most of the time he lacks emotion in his role, which makes the relationship with his son hard for me to care a lot about, and that makes the whole premise of why he's doing all this falter. Russell Crowe does a fantastic job in his role, and was easily the best part of this movie. No other characters are particularly remarkable, which again is a trademark of Westerns, and the action is top notch for what it tries to do. But Bale's failure to engage his role in the capacity it requires makes this movie not as good as it should be, but it's still a good movie that I would recommend.

Dallas Roberts as the guy with the money surpasses the limits of his role, he's a character actor to look out for, and it's always good to see Serenity's pilot Alan Tudyk. 3:10 to Yuma didn't move me as much as I had hoped it would. Christian Bale's character doesn't really progress through the film, and what begins as righteousness becomes more like stubbornness. Russell Crowe's character is confusing and seems to fluctuate as it pleases without obvious reason - is he bad? Is he good? Is he having some kind of redemption? It is definitely hard to discern his motives for ignoring his entire gang in the final scenes - which, to give them credit, were well-done - and then shooting them all.  Confusing, or just lacking explanation.
Another point, which is more of personal preference, was that I thought there was too much shooting. Pistols and shotguns are a staple of Westerns - but when they're happily and endlessly fired off at each other throughout the film they lose their impact. Old pistols and shotguns are incredibly loud and modern films really have the technological capability to show us that. I prefer the approach taken by the modern reboot of True Grit, where the pistols are used sparingly and after the half-way mark - we've been waiting for someone to fire a shot, and when they do, it's incredibly loud.
